question.title: Why does a Java method with a interface type fails to recognize this overloaded method?
question.body:
I'm studying for a exam and came across the following problem:

IntfX is a interface in package A, and contains the method public void op_a(Double e)

CIsY is a class in package A that implements IntfX and overrides op_a.

In package B, the Main class imports package A, extends CIsY and proceeds to overload op_a as public void op_a(Double e, Double f)

Now in the psvm block, there's two instantiations: Intfx a = new Main(), and Main b = new Main()

Them it proceeds to call a.op_a(Double e, Double f) and c.op_a(Double e, Double f)

The a.op_a call fails. It shows a compilation time error "expect 1 arguments but found 2"

My question is: why does the a object fails to use the overloaded method op_a with 2 arguments? In another problems, when there's two versions of a method, the jvm gives preference to the object, not the type.

The code:

`package A:

public interface IntfX {
        public void op_a(Double a);
        public void op_b(Double b);
    }


public class CIsY implements IntfX {
    protected double v = 0.0;
    String p = null;

    public CIsY(Double x, String b) {
        v = x;
        p = b;
    }

    public void op_a(Double a) {
        v += a;
    }

    public void op_b(Double b) {
        v -= b;
    }

    public void op_c() {
        v = 0.0;
        p = null;
    }
}

Package B:

import pack_a.*;

public class Main extends CIsY{
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        IntfX a = new Main();
        CIsY b = new Main();
        Men c = new Main();

        c.op_a(0.5,0.8);
        a.op_a(0.0, 0.1);
    }
    public Main() {
        super(0.0, "");
    }

    public void op_a(Double e, Double f) {
        v = e + f;
    }

    public void  op_b(Double e, Double f) {
        v = e + f;
    }

    public void op_K(Double d) {
        v = d;
    }
}

I expected to a.op_a be able to recognize the overloaded method and compile.
